ground_truth: The Black Guy has his I.D. folder open as Ray Bones then walks off, and we see coming out a different gate, two big guys in sunglasses flanking one smaller, older guy. He looks over his shoulder to give the guy a smile. The agents glance at each other without giving any kind of sign. He straightens up as Chili exits the stairwell and walks up to him. Chili looks at him, the guy's either dumb or making conversation. The Bear keeps staring but doesn't say anything. The Bear looks at him. The Bear nods, closing and opening his eyes. Harry, his hair a mess from sleeping on it, looks up at the door as it opens to reveal Ray Bones standing there. He jerks upright. Harry wakes up quick, nearly wets himself as Bones then casually steps into the office. Scrambling now to play it the way Chili taught him, Harry quickly gestures to the red leather chair across the desk. As Ray Bones sits down, Harry moves to the blinds and opens them. Problem is, the sun's setting, so there's no glare at all. Ray indicates the nice red sunset. Harry just smiles, sits down at the desk, things already not going too well, about to get worse. Bo Catlett is behind a big wooden desk on the phone. The Bear, sort of half doubled over, sees three dark-shaded gentlemen step out of the car. Bo Catlett looks into the outer office as a car pulls into the garage. Bo Catlett hangs up, gets to his feet as the men all look into the office now. We can now see that one of the Latinos is older, the other two, younger, are his bodyguards. Mr. Escobar, the older, meaner one, steps into the office. As the two back doors of a limo slam shut, Bo Catlett sits in the back, wedged in between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has removed his shades. He faces Escobar on the opposite seat. Escobar studies him a moment. Bo Catlett stiffens. Bo Catlett shrugs. Bo Catlett barely glances at the bodyguards, smiles the gleamy smile to the Latin guy in front of him. As Ronnie zigzags in and out of traffic, giving people 'the look' as he passes, he is on the carphone. Bo Catlett is on the phone. Bones leans forward; Ray's heard that one before. Bones shakes his head, stands up, and begins kicking the living shit out of Harry Zimm. Ray Bones pulls a pair of black leather gloves from his pocket and steps around the desk. Bones grabs him by the hair, picks him up, and throws him across the room into the wall of pictures, many of them coming off their hooks and falling on top of Harry.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: The Black Fellow has his I.D. dossier open as Ray Bones then strolls off, and we observe emerging out a distinct entrance, two large fellows in sunglasses flanking one smaller, older fellow. He peers over his shoulder to give the fellow a grin. The agents peer at each other without providing any sort of indication. He straightens as Chili leaves the stairwell and approaches him. Chili peers at him, the fellow's either dull or making dialogue. The Bear keeps gazing but doesn't utter anything. The Bear peers at him. The Bear nods, shutting and opening his eyes. Harry, his hair a disarray from slumbering on it, peers up at the door as it opens to expose Ray Bones standing there. He jerks upright. Harry rouses quickly, nearly wets himself as Bones then nonchalantly steps into the office. Scrambling now to perform it the way Chili instructed him, Harry swiftly signals to the crimson leather chair across the desk. As Ray Bones sits down, Harry moves to the blinds and opens them. Problem is, the sun's descending, so there's no glare at all. Ray indicates the pleasant red sundown. Harry just grins, sits down at the desk, matters already not proceeding too well, about to worsen. Bo Catlett is behind a large wooden desk on the phone. The Bear, sort of half doubled over, observes three dark-tinted gentlemen emerge from the car. Bo Catlett peers into the outer office as a car maneuvers into the garage. Bo Catlett hangs up, rises to his feet as the men all peer into the office now. We can now observe that one of the Latinos is older, the other two, younger, are his protectors. Mr. Escobar, the older, meaner one, steps into the office. As the two rear doors of a limousine slam shut, Bo Catlett sits in the back, wedged between the two protectors, neither of whom has removed his shades. He faces Escobar on the opposite seat. Escobar examines him a moment. Bo Catlett stiffens. Bo Catlett shrugs. Bo Catlett barely glances at the protectors, grins the gleamy grin to the Latin fellow in front of him. As Ronnie zigzags in and out of traffic, giving individuals 'the look' as he passes, he is on the carphone. Bo Catlett is on the phone. Bones leans forward; Ray's heard that one before. Bones shakes his head, stands up, and begins kicking the living crap out of Harry Zimm. Ray Bones pulls a pair of black leather gloves from his pocket and steps around the desk. Bones seizes him by the hair, lifts him up, and hurls him across the chamber into the wall of pictures, many of them coming off their hooks and falling atop Harry.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: The I.D. folder is kept open by the Black Guy as Ray Bones then walks off, and coming out a different gate, we see two big guys in sunglasses flanking one smaller, older guy. A smile is given by him over his shoulder to the guy. Each other is glanced at by the agents without giving any kind of sign. He straightens up as the stairwell is exited by Chili and he walks up to him. He is looked at by Chili, the guy's either dumb or making conversation. Staring is kept by The Bear, but he doesn't say anything. At him, The Bear looks. The Bear nods, closing and opening his eyes. Harry's hair, messed from sleeping on it, is looked up at the door by him as it is opened to reveal Ray Bones standing there. He jerks upright. Harry quickly awakens, nearly wetting himself as the office is casually stepped into by Bones. Scrambling now to play it the way Chili taught him, the red leather chair across the desk is quickly gestured to by Harry. As the chair is sat down in by Ray Bones, Harry moves to the blinds and opens them. The problem is highlighted by the sun's setting, so no glare is present at all. The nice red sunset is indicated by Ray. Smiling, Harry just sits down at the desk, things already not going too well, about to get worse. A big wooden desk is where Bo Catlett sits, on the phone. The three dark-shaded gentlemen are seen stepping out of the car by The Bear, sort of half-doubled over. The outer office is looked into by Bo Catlett as the garage is pulled into by a car. The phone is hung up by Bo Catlett, and he gets to his feet as the office is looked into now by the men. It can now be seen that one of the Latinos is older, while the other two, younger, act as his bodyguards. The office is stepped into by Mr. Escobar, the older, meaner one. The two back doors of a limo slam shut, and the back seat is occupied by Bo Catlett, wedged in between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has removed his shades. The opposite seat is where Escobar faces him. Escobar takes a moment to study him. A stiff posture is taken by Bo Catlett. A shrug is given by Bo Catlett. The bodyguards are barely glanced at by Bo Catlett, who smiles the gleamy smile at the Latin guy in front of him. As traffic is zigzagged in and out by Ronnie, giving people 'the look' as they are passed, he talks on the carphone. The phone is used by Bo Catlett. A forward lean is taken by Bones; Ray's heard that one before. A shake of his head is given by Bones, who stands up and begins kicking the living shit out of Harry Zimm. A pair of black leather gloves is pulled from his pocket by Ray Bones, who steps around the desk. Harry is grabbed by the hair by Bones, who picks him up and throws him across the room into the wall of pictures, many of them coming off their hooks and falling on top of Harry.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The Black Guy opens his I.D. folder as Ray Bones walks off. From another gate, two big men in sunglasses flank a smaller, older man, who smiles over his shoulder. The agents glance at each other with no reaction. He straightens up as Chili exits the stairwell and approaches. Chili watches him—he's either clueless or making conversation. The Bear keeps staring silently, nodding with a slow blink. Harry, hair disheveled from sleep, looks up as Ray Bones enters. He bolts upright, startled, nearly wetting himself as Bones steps in. Trying to follow Chili’s advice, Harry gestures to the red leather chair. As Bones sits, Harry opens the blinds, but the setting sun causes no glare. Ray points to the red sunset; Harry just smiles and sits, things already going badly. Bo Catlett, behind a large wooden desk on the phone, notices three men—two bodyguards with an older Latino—exit a car. As a limo pulls in, Catlett hangs up and stands as they look into the office. Mr. Escobar, the older, meaner one, enters. Later, in the limo, Bo Catlett sits wedged between the guards, facing Escobar. Escobar studies him. Catlett stiffens, shrugs, and barely glances at the guards, flashing a fake smile at Escobar. Meanwhile, Ronnie weaves through traffic on the carphone. Bo Catlett is also on a call. Bones, unimpressed, stands and kicks the crap out of Harry Zimm. Ray Bones pulls on black gloves, grabs Harry by the hair, hurls him into a wall of photos, many crashing down on him.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The Black Guy has his I.D. folder open as Ray Bones walks off. Two big guys in sunglasses flank a smaller, older man, who smiles over his shoulder. The agents exchange glances. Chili exits the stairwell and approaches. The Bear stares but remains silent, nodding. Harry, hair messy from sleep, sees Ray Bones enter and jerks upright, nearly wetting himself. He gestures to the red leather chair as Bones sits. Harry opens the blinds, but the sunset causes no glare. Ray comments on the sunset. Harry smiles, uneasy. Bo Catlett, on the phone behind a desk, sees three men exit a car. He hangs up as they enter. Mr. Escobar, older and meaner, enters with two bodyguards. Bo Catlett sits between them in a limo, facing Escobar, who studies him. Bo Catlett shrugs and smiles at Escobar. Ronnie zigzags through traffic on the carphone. Bo Catlett is also on the phone. Bones leans forward, shakes his head, stands, and attacks Harry Zimm. Ray Bones puts on black leather gloves, grabs Harry by the hair, and throws him into a wall, knocking down pictures.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description:
The Black Guy, with his identification folder prominently open, stands by as Ray Bones casually walks away. Meanwhile, emerging from a different gate, we observe two large men wearing sunglasses, flanking a smaller, older gentleman. This older man glances over his shoulder, offering a friendly smile to the guy. The agents exchange glances with each other, yet they refrain from giving any overt sign or signal. The older man straightens up just as Chili emerges from the stairwell and approaches him. Chili looks at the man, who seems either oblivious or simply attempting to make conversation. The Bear continues to stare intently but remains silent. The Bear maintains his gaze, nodding slightly, and briefly closes and opens his eyes.

Inside, Harry, whose hair is disheveled from having slept on it, looks up at the door as it swings open to reveal Ray Bones standing there. Startled, he jerks upright. Harry quickly awakens, nearly wetting himself in surprise as Bones nonchalantly steps into the office. In a hurried attempt to handle the situation as Chili had instructed him, Harry gestures quickly to the red leather chair positioned across the desk. As Ray Bones takes a seat, Harry moves to the blinds and opens them. Unfortunately, the sun is setting, so there is no glare to contend with. Ray gestures toward the pleasant red sunset. Harry merely smiles, takes his seat at the desk, aware that things are already not going well and are about to deteriorate further.

Meanwhile, Bo Catlett is seated behind a large wooden desk, engaged in a phone conversation. The Bear, somewhat hunched over, observes as three men wearing dark sunglasses step out of a car. Bo Catlett peers into the outer office as a vehicle pulls into the garage. He hangs up the phone and rises to his feet as the men now direct their attention toward the office. It becomes apparent that one of the Latinos is older, while the other two, younger men serve as his bodyguards. Mr. Escobar, the older and more intimidating figure, steps into the office. As the two back doors of a limousine slam shut, Bo Catlett finds himself seated in the back, wedged between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has removed his sunglasses. He faces Escobar, who is seated on the opposite side. Escobar scrutinizes him for a moment, causing Bo Catlett to stiffen. Bo Catlett shrugs slightly, barely glancing at the bodyguards, and offers a gleaming smile to the Latin man seated in front of him.

Elsewhere, Ronnie weaves in and out of traffic, giving people 'the look' as he passes, all while talking on the car phone. Bo Catlett is also on the phone. Bones leans forward, having heard that particular line before. Bones shakes his head, stands up, and begins to violently assault Harry Zimm. Ray Bones retrieves a pair of black leather gloves from his pocket and steps around the desk. He grabs Harry by the hair, lifts him up, and hurls him across the room into a wall adorned with pictures, many of which come off their hooks and crash down on top of Harry.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description:
The Black Guy, with his identification folder prominently displayed and wide open for all to see, stands by attentively as Ray Bones nonchalantly saunters away from the scene. Meanwhile, from a different gate altogether, we observe two large, imposing men wearing dark sunglasses. They flank a smaller, older gentleman who possesses an air of significance. This older man, displaying a friendly demeanor, glances over his shoulder, offering a warm and amiable smile to the guy. The agents exchange significant glances with one another, yet they refrain from giving any overt sign or signal, maintaining their composure. The older man straightens up just as Chili emerges from the stairwell and approaches him with purpose. Chili looks at the man, who seems either intentionally oblivious or simply attempting to make conversation without really engaging. The Bear continues to fixate intently but remains silent and impassive. The Bear maintains his unwavering gaze, nodding ever so slightly, and briefly closes and opens his eyes in a subtle gesture.

Inside, we find Harry, whose hair is thoroughly disheveled from having been slept on, looking up at the door as it swings open to reveal Ray Bones standing there. Startled, Harry jerks upright with a sudden motion. Harry quickly awakens, nearly wetting himself in surprise as Bones nonchalantly steps into the office, as if he owns it. In a hurried attempt to handle the situation just as Chili had instructed him, Harry gestures quickly and somewhat nervously to the red leather chair positioned across the desk. As Ray Bones takes his seat with a sense of authority, Harry moves to the blinds and opens them with urgency. Unfortunately for him, the sun is setting, so there is no blinding glare to contend with. Ray gestures toward the pleasant, picturesque red sunset in the distance. Harry merely smiles, albeit somewhat anxiously, and takes his seat at the desk, fully aware that things are already not going well and are most likely about to deteriorate further.

Meanwhile, Bo Catlett is seated behind a large, imposing wooden desk and is deeply engaged in a phone conversation. The Bear, somewhat hunched over in his stance, observes as three men clad in dark sunglasses step out of a car with a sense of purpose. Bo Catlett peers into the outer office as a vehicle pulls into the garage with precision. He hangs up the phone and rises to his feet as the men now direct their full attention toward the office. It becomes increasingly apparent that one of the Latinos is older, while the other two, younger men serve as his vigilant bodyguards. Mr. Escobar, the older and more intimidating figure of the three, steps into the office with authority. As the two back doors of a limousine slam shut with finality, Bo Catlett finds himself seated in the back, wedged between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has removed his dark sunglasses. He faces Escobar, who is seated on the opposite side with a scrutinizing gaze. Escobar scrutinizes him for a moment, causing Bo Catlett to stiffen slightly in response. Bo Catlett shrugs slightly, barely daring to glance at the bodyguards, and offers a gleaming smile to the Latin man seated in front of him.

Elsewhere, Ronnie deftly weaves in and out of traffic, giving people 'the look' as he smoothly passes, all while talking animatedly on the car phone. Simultaneously, Bo Catlett is also engaged in a phone conversation. Bones leans forward, having heard that particular line before, causing him to react. Bones shakes his head, stands up abruptly, and begins to violently assault Harry Zimm in a sudden, unexpected outburst. Ray Bones retrieves a pair of sleek black leather gloves from his pocket and steps around the desk with intent. He grabs Harry by the hair with force, lifts him up as if he weighs nothing, and hurls him across the room into a wall adorned with pictures. Many of these pictures, unable to withstand the impact, come off their hooks and crash down on top of Harry in a chaotic cascade.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The Black Guy stands with his I.D. folder open, observing as Ray Bones walks away. Meanwhile, emerging from a different gate, two large men wearing sunglasses flank a smaller, older man. The older man glances over his shoulder, offering a smile to the guy. The agents exchange glances without any overt communication. As Chili exits the stairwell, he approaches the older man, who either lacks awareness or is attempting to make conversation. The Bear maintains his gaze, remaining silent, and then nods, briefly closing and reopening his eyes. Harry, with his hair disheveled from sleep, looks up as the door opens to reveal Ray Bones standing there. Startled, Harry jerks upright, waking quickly and nearly losing control as Bones casually enters the office. In a hurried attempt to follow Chili's instructions, Harry gestures towards the red leather chair across the desk. As Ray Bones takes a seat, Harry moves to the blinds and opens them, only to find that the setting sun provides no glare. Ray comments on the pleasant red sunset, prompting Harry to smile and sit down at the desk, aware that things are already going poorly and are about to worsen. Bo Catlett, seated behind a large wooden desk, is on the phone. The Bear, slightly hunched over, observes three men in dark shades stepping out of a car. Bo Catlett looks towards the outer office as a car pulls into the garage, then hangs up and stands as the men peer into the office. It becomes clear that one of the Latinos is older, while the other two, younger, serve as his bodyguards. Mr. Escobar, the older and more intimidating figure, enters the office. As the limo's back doors slam shut, Bo Catlett finds himself in the back, wedged between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has removed their sunglasses. He faces Escobar, who scrutinizes him for a moment, causing Bo Catlett to stiffen and then shrug. Bo Catlett barely acknowledges the bodyguards, instead offering a gleaming smile to the Latin man before him. Meanwhile, Ronnie weaves through traffic, giving other drivers 'the look' as he passes, all while on the car phone. Bo Catlett is also on the phone. Bones leans forward, having heard the story before, and shakes his head. He stands up and begins to violently assault Harry Zimm. Ray Bones retrieves a pair of black leather gloves from his pocket, steps around the desk, grabs Harry by the hair, lifts him, and hurls him across the room into a wall adorned with pictures, many of which fall from their hooks and land on top of Harry.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The Black Guy holds his I.D. folder open as Ray Bones departs, and two large men in sunglasses escort a smaller, older man through a different gate. The older man smiles over his shoulder, while the agents exchange glances without signaling. As Chili exits the stairwell and approaches, the older man either feigns ignorance or engages in conversation, while The Bear silently observes and nods. Meanwhile, Harry, disheveled from sleep, is startled awake by Ray Bones entering his office. Quickly recalling Chili's advice, Harry gestures to a red leather chair for Ray, who sits as Harry opens the blinds, revealing a sunset. Ray comments on the sunset, and Harry, sensing trouble, sits at his desk. In another scene, Bo Catlett, on the phone behind a large desk, notices three men exiting a car. He hangs up as Mr. Escobar, an older man with two younger bodyguards, enters the office. Later, Bo Catlett is in a limo, seated between the bodyguards, facing Escobar, who scrutinizes him. Bo Catlett responds with a smile, barely acknowledging the bodyguards. Meanwhile, Ronnie weaves through traffic on a car phone, and Bo Catlett is also on a call. Ray Bones, having heard enough, stands and violently assaults Harry Zimm, pulling on black leather gloves, grabbing Harry by the hair, and throwing him into a wall of pictures, causing them to fall on top of him.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The Black Guy, who is an undercover agent for a federal agency, has his I.D. folder open as Ray Bones, a notorious enforcer for a crime syndicate, then walks off. We see coming out a different gate, two big guys in sunglasses flanking one smaller, older guy, a testament to their role as personal security detail possibly for a high-level crime boss. He looks over his shoulder to give the guy a smile, a customary gesture to assure his entourage. The agents, trained in covert operations, glance at each other without giving any kind of sign, a technique to avoid detection. He straightens up as Chili, a former small-time Miami loan shark now trying to break into the movie business, exits the stairwell and walks up to him. Chili looks at him, the guy's either dumb or making conversation, a common tactic in negotiations. The Bear, a well-known Hollywood stuntman turned enforcer, keeps staring but doesn't say anything, a gesture often used to convey dominance. The Bear looks at him. The Bear nods, closing and opening his eyes, a non-verbal cue used in agreements. Harry, a struggling film producer known for his chaotic lifestyle, his hair a mess from sleeping on it, looks up at the door as it opens to reveal Ray Bones standing there. He jerks upright. Harry wakes up quick, nearly wets himself as Bones then casually steps into the office, a scene reminiscent of many Hollywood portrayals of intimidation. Scrambling now to play it the way Chili taught him, Harry quickly gestures to the red leather chair across the desk, a chair known to belong to a famous actor who frequented the office. As Ray Bones sits down, Harry moves to the blinds and opens them. Problem is, the sun's setting over the Los Angeles skyline, so there's no glare at all. Ray indicates the nice red sunset, an atmospheric detail that often symbolizes impending danger in cinema. Harry just smiles, sits down at the desk, things already not going too well, about to get worse. Bo Catlett, a smooth-talking film financier with shady connections, is behind a big wooden desk on the phone. The Bear, sort of half doubled over, sees three dark-shaded gentlemen step out of the car, likely members of a rival faction. Bo Catlett looks into the outer office as a car pulls into the garage, signaling an arrival that could shift the power dynamics. Bo Catlett hangs up, gets to his feet as the men all look into the office now, creating tension. We can now see that one of the Latinos is older, the other two, younger, are his bodyguards, indicating a hierarchy within their organization. Mr. Escobar, the older, meaner one, steps into the office, his reputation preceding him as a feared cartel leader. As the two back doors of a limo slam shut, Bo Catlett sits in the back, wedged in between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has removed his shades, a move that maintains their anonymity and intimidation. He faces Escobar on the opposite seat. Escobar studies him a moment, a strategic pause often used to unsettle. Bo Catlett stiffens. Bo Catlett shrugs, a nonchalant response to mask his unease. Bo Catlett barely glances at the bodyguards, smiles the gleamy smile to the Latin guy in front of him, aware that any sign of disrespect could be lethal. As Ronnie zigzags in and out of Los Angeles traffic, giving people 'the look' as he passes, he is on the carphone, a high-risk activity blending business with the thrill of adrenaline. Bo Catlett is on the phone. Bones leans forward; Ray's heard that one before, his skepticism rooted in years of dealing with deceptive adversaries. Bones shakes his head, stands up, and begins kicking the living shit out of Harry Zimm, an act of violence to send a message. Ray Bones pulls a pair of black leather gloves from his pocket and steps around the desk, gloves often used to avoid leaving fingerprints. Bones grabs him by the hair, picks him up, and throws him across the room into the wall of pictures, many of them autographed snapshots of Hollywood stars, coming off their hooks and falling on top of Harry.

The Bear sort of half doubled over sees. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. test_cases.name: Subject Corruption
test_cases.description: The giraffe has its I.D. folder open as the penguin then walks off, and we see coming out a different gate, two robots in sunglasses flanking one smaller, older robot. The turtle looks over its shoulder to give the robot a smile. The kangaroos glance at each other without giving any kind of sign. The squirrel straightens up as the dolphin exits the stairwell and walks up to it. The dolphin looks at it, the robot's either dumb or making conversation. The rabbit keeps staring but doesn't say anything. The rabbit looks at it. The rabbit nods, closing and opening its eyes. The panda, its hair a mess from sleeping on it, looks up at the door as it opens to reveal the penguin standing there. The panda jerks upright. The panda wakes up quick, nearly wets itself as the penguin then casually steps into the office. Scrambling now to play it the way the dolphin taught it, the panda quickly gestures to the red leather chair across the desk. As the penguin sits down, the panda moves to the blinds and opens them. Problem is, the sun's setting, so there's no glare at all. The penguin indicates the nice red sunset. The panda just smiles, sits down at the desk, things already not going too well, about to get worse. The octopus is behind a big wooden desk on the phone. The rabbit, sort of half doubled over, sees three dark-shaded aliens step out of the car. The octopus looks into the outer office as a car pulls into the garage. The octopus hangs up, gets to its feet as the aliens all look into the office now. We can now see that one of the hedgehogs is older, the other two, younger, are its bodyguards. Mr. Platypus, the older, meaner one, steps into the office. As the two back doors of a limo slam shut, the octopus sits in the back, wedged in between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has removed its shades. It faces Platypus on the opposite seat. Platypus studies it a moment. The octopus stiffens. The octopus shrugs. The octopus barely glances at the bodyguards, smiles the gleamy smile to the hedgehog in front of it. As the raccoon zigzags in and out of traffic, giving people 'the look' as it passes, it is on the carphone. The octopus is on the phone. The penguin leans forward; the penguin's heard that one before. The penguin shakes its head, stands up, and begins kicking the living shit out of the koala. The penguin pulls a pair of black leather gloves from its pocket and steps around the desk. The penguin grabs it by the hair, picks it up, and throws it across the room into the wall of pictures, many of them coming off their hooks and falling on top of the koala.

test_cases.name: Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The Black Guy has his manual open as Ray Bones then walks off, and we see coming out a different port, two big guys in watches flanking one smaller, older guy. He looks over his shoulder to give the guy a grin. The agents glance at each other without giving any kind of clue. He straightens up as Chili exits the elevator and walks up to him. Chili looks at him, the guy's either confused or making conversation. The Bear keeps staring but doesn't say anything. The Bear looks at him. The Bear nods, closing and opening his eyes. Harry, his hair a mess from lying on it, looks up at the hatch as it opens to reveal Ray Bones standing there. He jerks upright. Harry wakes up quick, nearly wets himself as Bones then casually steps into the study. Scrambling now to play it the way Chili taught him, Harry quickly gestures to the green velvet couch across the room. As Ray Bones sits down, Harry moves to the curtains and opens them. Problem is, the moon's rising, so there's no glare at all. Ray indicates the nice blue moonrise. Harry just smiles, sits down at the table, things already not going too well, about to get worse. Bo Catlett is behind a big metal table on the phone. The Bear, sort of half doubled over, sees three mirrored gentlemen step out of the van. Bo Catlett looks into the outer room as a truck pulls into the lot. Bo Catlett hangs up, gets to his feet as the men all look into the study now. We can now see that one of the Latinos is older, the other two, younger, are his bodyguards. Mr. Escobar, the older, meaner one, steps into the study. As the two back doors of a taxi slam shut, Bo Catlett sits in the back, wedged in between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has removed his hats. He faces Escobar on the opposite bench. Escobar studies him a moment. Bo Catlett stiffens. Bo Catlett shrugs. Bo Catlett barely glances at the bodyguards, smiles the gleamy smile to the Latin guy in front of him. As Ronnie zigzags in and out of alleys, giving people 'the glance' as he passes, he is on the bicycle. Bo Catlett is on the phone. Bones leans forward; Ray's heard that one before. Bones shakes his head, stands up, and begins kicking the living crap out of Harry Zimm. Ray Bones pulls a pair of brown wool gloves from his pocket and steps around the table. Bones grabs him by the neck, picks him up, and throws him across the chamber into the wall of posters, many of them coming off their hooks and falling on top of Harry.

test_cases.name: Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The Black Guy has his I.D. folder closed as Ray Bones then skips off, and we see coming out a different gate, two big guys in sunglasses carrying one smaller, older guy. He turns his back to give the guy a thumbs up. The agents whisper to each other without making any kind of gesture. He crouches down as Chili leaps out of the stairwell and dances up to him. Chili stares at him, the guy's either clueless or writing poetry. The Bear keeps pacing but doesn't whisper anything. The Bear glances at him. The Bear twitches, slamming and punching his eyes. Harry, his hair a mess from napping on it, glances up at the door as it springs open to show Ray Bones waving there. He stretches out. Harry dozes off quick, almost jumps out of his skin as Bones then nonchalantly drifts into the office. Dancing now to shake it the way Chili instructed him, Harry quickly points to the red leather chair across the desk. As Ray Bones hops down, Harry runs to the blinds and lowers them. Problem is, the sun's rising, so there's a bright glare everywhere. Ray points to the nice red sunrise. Harry just frowns, reclines at the desk, things already spiraling, about to get better. Bo Catlett is behind a big wooden desk on the phone. The Bear, sort of half skipping over, notices three dark-shaded gentlemen stepping into the car. Bo Catlett peeks into the outer office as a car drives into the bay. Bo Catlett puts down the phone, drops to his knees as the men all sing into the office now. We can now see that one of the Latinos is younger, the other two, older, are his bodyguards. Mr. Escobar, the younger, cheerier one, dances into the office. As the two back doors of a limo swing open, Bo Catlett stands on the roof, wedged in between the two bodyguards, neither of whom has shifted his shades. He nods at Escobar on the opposite seat. Escobar massages him a moment. Bo Catlett relaxes. Bo Catlett winces. Bo Catlett hardly notices the bodyguards, laughs the hearty laugh to the Latin guy in front of him. As Ronnie swerves in and out of traffic, sending people 'the wink' as he passes, he is on the carphone. Bo Catlett is on the line. Bones leans back; Ray's missed that one before. Bones winks his eye, kneels down, and starts tossing the living papers around Harry Zimm. Ray Bones slips a pair of black leather gloves from his pocket and sneaks around the desk. Bones nudges him by the shoulder, lifts him up, and swings him across the room into the wall of posters, many of them sliding off their hooks and floating on top of Harry.

test_cases.name: Subject-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The mailbox has its blueprint folder open as the raccoon then walks off, and we see coming out a different hut, two large flamingos in sunglasses flanking one smaller, older desk lamp. It looks over its shoulder to give the sponge a smile. The spoons glance at each other without giving any kind of sign. It straightens up as the pickle exits the tunnel and walks up to it. The pickle looks at it, the sponge's either dumb or making conversation. The sandwich keeps staring but doesn't say anything. The sandwich looks at it. The sandwich nods, closing and opening its eyes. The wind chime, its strings a tangle from resting on them, looks up at the drawer as it opens to reveal the raccoon standing there. It jerks upright. The wind chime wakes up quick, nearly wets itself as the raccoon then casually steps into the greenhouse. Scrambling now to play it the way the pickle taught it, the wind chime quickly gestures to the blue velvet couch across the carpet. As the raccoon sits down, the wind chime moves to the curtains and opens them. Problem is, the moon's rising, so there's no glare at all. The raccoon indicates the nice blue moonrise. The wind chime just smiles, sits down at the carpet, things already not going too well, about to get worse. The cactus is behind a big stone table on the intercom. The sandwich, sort of half doubled over, sees three dark-spectacled spoons step out of the wheelbarrow. The cactus looks into the outer greenhouse as a wheelbarrow pulls into the parking lot. The cactus hangs up, gets to its feet as the spoons all look into the greenhouse now. We can now see that one of the birds is older, the other two, younger, are its fireflies. Mr. Firefly, the older, meaner one, steps into the greenhouse. As the two back doors of a cart slam shut, the cactus sits in the back, wedged in between the two fireflies, neither of whom has removed its shades. It faces Firefly on the opposite seat. Firefly studies it a moment. The cactus stiffens. The cactus shrugs. The cactus barely glances at the fireflies, smiles the gleamy smile to the flamingo in front of it. As the seagull zigzags in and out of lightning, giving planets 'the look' as it passes, it is on the bicycle bell. The cactus is on the intercom. The raccoon leans forward; the raccoon's heard that one before. The raccoon shakes its head, stands up, and begins kicking the living shit out of the curtain rod. The raccoon pulls a pair of green denim mittens from its pocket and steps around the carpet. The raccoon grabs it by the tassel, picks it up, and throws it across the greenhouse into the wall of canvases, many of them coming off their nails and falling on top of the curtain rod.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The Gray Cat has its tail flicking as Sam Stones then saunters off, and we see coming out a different door, two small birds in hats escorting one larger, younger bird. It glances over its wing to give the bird a nod. The squirrels peer at each other without exchanging any kind of gesture. It hunches over as Pepper leaves the elevator and skips up to it. Pepper glances at it, the bird’s either clueless or engaging in chatter. The Moose keeps blinking but doesn’t utter anything. The Moose peers at it. The Moose waves, stretching and closing its eyes. Jerry, his feathers ruffled from nesting on them, peers at the window as it opens to reveal Sam Stones standing there. It leaps up. Jerry jolts awake, nearly pecks itself as Stones then lazily strides into the workshop. Scrambling now to act it the way Pepper showed him, Jerry swiftly points to the blue velvet stool across the table. As Sam Stones perches down, Jerry flutters to the curtains and closes them. Issue is, the moon's rising, so there's no shade at all. Sam gestures to the pretty blue moonrise. Jerry merely nods, perches down at the table, things already not looking too well, about to get worse. Joe Whiskers is behind a small metal chair on the phone. The Moose, sort of half sitting up, sees three light-winged doves step out of the bush. Joe Whiskers glances into the inner room as a bike rolls into the driveway. Joe Whiskers hangs up, jumps to its paws as the doves all peer into the room now. We can now see that one of the ravens is younger, the other two, elder, are its companions. Mr. Ravenclaw, the younger, kinder one, hops into the room. As the two back hatches of a cage click shut, Joe Whiskers perches in the back, squeezed between the two companions, neither of whom has removed its cap. It faces Ravenclaw on the opposite branch. Ravenclaw observes it a moment. Joe Whiskers relaxes. Joe Whiskers chuckles. Joe Whiskers barely peeks at the companions, grins the bright grin to the raven in front of it. As Ricky zigzags in and out of the field, giving animals 'the gaze' as it flutters, it is on the birdphone. Joe Whiskers is on the phone. Stones leans back; Sam's seen that one before. Stones shakes its head, stands up, and begins tossing the living fluff out of Jerry Zimm. Sam Stones pulls a pair of white satin mittens from its satchel and strolls around the table. Stones grips it by the feathers, hoists it up, and flings it across the room into the wall of drawings, many of them tumbling off their hooks and landing on top of Jerry.

test_cases.name: Object-Action Corruption
test_cases.description: The Black Guy has his address book open as Ray Bones then drifts off, and we see emerging from a different archway, two big guys in hats escorting one smaller, younger guy. He glances over his elbow to offer the guy a grin. The agents peer at each other without offering any kind of gesture. He props up as Chili leaves the tunnel and saunters up to him. Chili gazes at him, the guy's either clueless or exchanging pleasantries. The Bear keeps glaring but doesn't utter a word. The Bear peers at him. The Bear agrees, flickering his eyes open and shut. Harry, his hair a mess from tossing and turning on it, peers at the window as it slides open to expose Ray Bones waiting there. He springs upright. Harry jolts awake, almost spills his drink as Bones then leisurely glides into the workspace. Fumbling now to play it the way Chili instructed him, Harry quickly beckons to the blue velvet stool across the room. As Ray Bones perches down, Harry shifts to the curtains and parts them. Problem is, the moon's rising, so there's no shine at all. Ray gestures toward the nice blue twilight. Harry just grins, plops down at the table, things already off track, about to derail further. Bo Catlett is behind a big glass bench on the phone. The Bear, sort of half crouched over, notices three bright-coated gentlemen step out of the wagon. Bo Catlett peers into the inner chamber as a bicycle coasts into the driveway. Bo Catlett hangs up, rises to his toes as the men all peer into the chamber now. We can now see that one of the Europeans is older, the other two, younger, are his escorts. Mr. Escobar, the older, angrier one, strides into the chamber. As the two rear hatches of a van thump closed, Bo Catlett snuggles in the back, wedged in between the two escorts, neither of whom has removed his hats. He faces Escobar on the opposite cushion. Escobar surveys him a moment. Bo Catlett freezes. Bo Catlett shrugs. Bo Catlett barely glances at the escorts, grins the sparkly grin to the European guy in front of him. As Ronnie weaves in and out of pedestrians, giving people 'the glance' as he rides, he is on the walkie-talkie. Bo Catlett is on the walkie-talkie. Bones tilts forward; Ray's known that one before. Bones wags his finger, stands up, and begins tapping the living daylights out of Harry Zimm. Ray Bones pulls a pair of red velvet mittens from his backpack and strides around the table. Bones seizes him by the collar, lifts him up, and flings him across the space into the wall of paintings, many of them slipping off their hooks and tumbling onto Harry.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The Blue Cat has its travel brochure closed as Sam Stones then skips away, and we notice arriving from another tunnel, two small birds in hats flying beside one larger, younger bird. It glances over its wing to give the bird a frown. The lions blink at one another without displaying any kind of gesture. It hunches down as Pepper enters the elevator and skips over to it. Pepper glances at it, the bird's either wise or ignoring the radio. The Owl keeps glaring but doesn't hear anything. The Owl blinks at it. The Owl shakes its head, opening and closing its beak. Barry, his shirt a mess from lounging on it, glances at the window as it slides to reveal Sam Stones relaxing there. It jumps sideways. Barry drifts up slow, nearly drops himself as Stones then gracefully floats into the kitchen. Climbing now to play it the way Pepper showed it, Barry slowly signals to the blue velvet table beyond the counter. As Sam Stones reclines, Barry floats to the curtains and closes them. Problem is, the moon's rising, so there's tons of shine everywhere. Sam notes the beautiful blue sunrise. Barry merely frowns, reclines on the counter, things already going too smoothly, about to get better. Bo Fish is behind a small stone counter on the intercom. The Owl, kind of fully straightened up, notices four bright-feathered parrots fly out of the nest. Bo Fish frowns into the inner kitchen as a bird lands on the roof. Bo Fish picks up, drops to its knees as the birds all peek into the kitchen now. We can now notice that one of the robins is younger, the other two, older, are its relatives. Mr. Lark, the younger, kinder one, floats into the kitchen. As the two back windows of a taxi click open, Bo Fish stands on the roof, nestled in between the two relatives, neither of whom has put on a hat. It faces Lark on the close seat. Lark ignores it a while. Bo Fish slouches. Bo Fish stretches. Bo Fish fully stares at the relatives, frowns the dim frown to the Spanish bird beside it. As Ricky hops in and out of spaces, frowning at trees as it skips, it is on the walkie-talkie. Bo Fish is on the intercom. Stones slumps backward; Sam's seen that act again. Stones nods its wing, sits down, and begins tickling the running clock out of Barry Yimm. Sam Stones pushes a pair of orange silk socks from its hat and skips around the counter. Stones pats it on the back, props it down, and spins it across the roof into the ceiling of paintings, many of them slipping off their nails and floating beneath Barry.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The Black Guy shows his I.D. as Ray Bones walks off, revealing two big guys in sunglasses and a smaller, older man. Chili exits the stairwell and encounters the Bear, who remains silent but acknowledges him. Harry, disheveled from sleep, reacts with alarm when Ray Bones enters his office, scrambling to play it cool as Bones sits in a red chair, noting the sunset. Meanwhile, Bo Catlett is on the phone behind a desk as three men arrive, including Mr. Escobar and his bodyguards. Bo Catlett, now in a limo with Escobar, tries to remain calm. Ronnie navigates traffic while on the carphone, and Bones aggressively confronts Harry Zimm, throwing him into a wall of pictures, causing them to collapse onto him.

test_cases.name: Reverse Segments Order
test_cases.description: Bones grabs him by the hair picks him up and throws him across the room into the wall of pictures many of them coming off their hooks and falling on top of Harry Ray Bones pulls a pair of black leather gloves from his pocket and steps around the desk  Zimm  Bones shakes his head stands up and begins kicking the living shit out of Harry  Ray's heard that one before  Bones leans forward  Bo Catlett is on the phone  As Ronnie zigzags in and out of traffic giving people 'the look' as he passes he is on the carphone  Bo Catlett barely glances at the bodyguards smiles the gleamy smile to the Latin guy in front of him  Bo Catlett shrugs  Bo Catlett stiffens  Escobar studies him a moment  He faces Escobar on the opposite seat  As the two back doors of a limo slam shut Bo Catlett sits in the back wedged in between the two bodyguards neither of whom has removed his shades  one steps into the office  Mr Escobar the older meaner  the other two younger are his bodyguards  We can now see that one of the Latinos is older  Bo Catlett hangs up gets to his feet as the men all look into the office now  as a car pulls into the garage  Bo Catlett looks into the outer office  three darkshaded gentlemen step out of the car  The Bear sort of half doubled over sees  Bo Catlett is behind a big wooden desk on the phone  about to get worse  things already not going too well  Harry just smiles sits down at the desk  Ray indicates the nice red sunset  Problem is the sun's setting so there's no glare at all  As Ray Bones sits down Harry moves to the blinds and opens them  Harry quickly gestures to the red leather chair across the desk  Scrambling now to play it the way Chili taught him  Harry wakes up quick nearly wets himself as Bones then casually steps into the office  He jerks upright  Harry his hair a mess from sleeping on it looks up at the door as it opens to reveal Ray Bones standing there  The Bear nods closing and opening his eyes  The Bear looks at him  The Bear keeps staring but doesn't say anything  the guy's either dumb or making conversation  Chili looks at him  He straightens up as Chili exits the stairwell and walks up to him  The agents glance at each other without giving any kind of sign  He looks over his shoulder to give the guy a smile  The Black Guy has his ID folder open as Ray Bones then walks off and we see coming out a different gate two big guys in sunglasses flanking one smaller older guy
